definition: to harbor/to shelter
nest/pit or hollow on the human body/lair/den/place/to harbor or shelter/to hold in check/to bend/classifier for litters and broods
Tibet/Xizang 西藏
storehouse/depository/Buddhist or Taoist scripture
to conceal/to hide away/to harbor/to store/to collect

sentences.english: Federal agents knew the family had been sheltering criminals in their home.
sentences.chinese: 聯邦特工人員知道那家人一直在家裏窩藏罪犯。

sentences.english: Norman was arrested for abetting the crime because he helped the robbers hide in his house.
sentences.chinese: 諾曼因協助犯罪而被捕，他將搶劫犯窩藏在自己家裏。

sentences.english: It is an offense to litter handbills.
How many an innocent-looking apple is harbouring a worm in the bud.
sentences.chinese: 有多少無辜的一個前瞻性蘋果窩藏蠕蟲在萌芽狀態。

definition: to conspire to murder/to plot against sb's life
house arrest
variant of 誣衊|诬蔑[wu1 mie4]
to be in charge of something specific
to imprison
pain and itch/sufferings/importance/consequence
outward devotion but inner opposition (idiom); to pay lip service/to agree overtly, but oppose in secret
to denounce/to condemn/to call to account/to punish
to frame sb/to accuse falsely
to take a risk out of desperation (idiom)
to eliminate/to sack/to remove from office
military leadership/military power
to banish (to an army post, as a punishment)
to beat sb at their own game (idiom)
to involve others (in a crime)/guilt by association
lit. helping tyrant Zhou 商紂王|商纣王[Shang1 Zhou4 wang2] in his oppression (idiom)/fig. to take the side of the evildoer/giving succor to the enemy
